Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics and Predictability of Tropical Weather and Climate through Cloud-resolving Ensemble Assimilation of Sounding and Radar Observations from DYNAMO
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO), which is the dominant mode of the tropical atmosphere at intraseasonal time scales, has significant impacts on many aspects of weather and climate across the globe. While the basic features of the MJO have been revealed by observations for many years, its underlying dynamics remain poorly understood and current generation numerical weather and climate models have low skills in simulating and predicting MJO events. The recently completed NSF-sponsored Dynamics of the Madden-Julian Oscillation (DYNAMO) field campaign targeted processes critically related to MJO initiation in the Indian Ocean.

This grant seeks to use ensemble-based data assimilation (EnDA) based on the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model to explore the dynamics and predictability of tropical weather and climate from convective to intraseasonal scales by assimilating radar, sounding, and satellite observations collected during DYNAMO. The DYNAMO observations of particular interest to the research are those from three Doppler radars, and those from an enhanced mesoscale sounding network.

Major objectives of the research include: (1) exploring the most reliable and effective EnDA methods for tropical weather analysis and forecasts ranging from convective to regional scales by comparing different variational, ensemble-based and hybrid data assimilation approaches; (2) conducting convective- and regional-scale reanalysis using the most accurate and affordable EnDA method over the entire DYNAMO period, and verify with regular and field observations as well as existing global analysis or reanalysis; and (3) examining the dynamics and predictability of tropical weather and climate (including the MJO) from convective to intraseasonal scales using convection-permitting (i.e., very high temporal and spatial resolution) ensemble analysis and forecasting.

Intellectual merits: The combination of the EnDA technique with field observations constitutes a potentially significant advance in data assimilation, and our understanding of the dynamics, evolution, prediction, and predictability of tropical weather and climate from convective to intraseasonal scales. The analysis and forecasts also provide an efficient pathway to bridge the understandings of tropical weather and climate from convective to intraseasonal scales.

Broader impacts: The research efforts will provide educational benefits through the extensive participation of a doctoral graduate student and a postdoctoral scientist. Research findings will also be directly used in classroom teaching and for directing undergraduate research projects. The findings on the initialization, prediction, and predictability of MJO events will improve operational forecasts of tropical weather and climate, providing a direct benefit to the general public, whether they live in the tropics or in areas around the world that are affected by MJO events. The EnDA systems developed from this support, and the reanalysis of DYNAMO observations by WRF simulations, will be made freely available online with ample documentation to benefit the larger academic community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) is the major weather disturbance moving eastward every 30 to 60 days in the tropical regions.  Although it occurs near the equator, the MJO influences weather globally. Thus prediction of the MJO may allow weather forecasts to be made with some skill as far as two to four weeks in the future, in the United States as well as elsewhere. Nevertheless, computer models used to model and predict the MJO are imperfect; and prediction skill for the MJO is very limited, particularly in the Indian Ocean where the MJO begins to form. Scientists still do not understood very well why the MJO exists and what influences the MJO initiation in the tropical ocean.  

This project seeks to improve our understanding of the MJOs observed during the October and December 2011, when a major international field experiment was conducted to study the initiation of the MJO in the Indian Ocean. This project combines numerous observational data collected during this field experiment with a new approach of computational simulations to explore these MJOs. This computational approach differs from conventional computer modeling in that they last much longer (more than 2 months) than typical weather models (a few days); and they are able to capture the important rain and cloud processes, much better than mainstream climate models. Results from this project indicate that this approach is effective and computationally efficient for the studies of the MJO.

Detailed computer simulations have been performed during the project, and several conditions for the simulations have been altered to see what happens to the MJOs. Because the MJO typically forms in the warm tropical ocean, scientists have long suspected that variations in time in the sea surface temperature (SST) are crucial for the MJO initiation. To answer this question, simulations with and without daily variations in SST are conducted. Results from these altered simulations are contrasted. As shown in attache figure, rain and winds during October are similar in both simulations, but differ greatly in November. This is strong evidence that daily variations in SST play an important role for the November MJO event, but much less so for the October MJO. Other potentially important factors for the MJO include influences from extratropical regions and from the west. A series of computational experiments are further conducted to examine how these factors influence the October MJO by removing them in the computational simulations. Results indicate that winds from the west play an important role in the initiation and propagation of this MJO event, while those from the higher latitudes have little effect. Together, these computational experiments have improved scientists' understanding of the MJOs observed during a major scientific experiment.

The MJO moves through many densely populated islands in the tropical regions. Scientists know little how and why the MJO may change rain and weather over tropical islands. To understand this question, computational experiments are conducted. These experiments are highly idealized as they are designed to keep all the essential meteorological elements while leave out all the non-essentials. Wind speeds, island size, and island topography are altered one by one in these simulations. Analysis of these simulations reveals a new result: rain is much enhanced when wind speed is either very week or strong, but less so when wind speed is a few meter per second. This is also consistent with satellite derived surface rain rates.
